lines.text: I'm beginning to think that "ER" stands for "everyone's retarded".

[leaving Luka a message]
Luka, this is Kerry Weaver. I'm down two attendings and up 40 patients. If you don't get in here and start working your scheduled shifts, I'm gonna call the INS, tell 'em your greencard's a fake, and have your ass deported
I don't even know who she is!
She knows who you are.
I don't think so.
Oh, Luka, every woman who works in the hospital knows who you are. Trust me.
Hey Jerry, don't we have a 'Lost and now is ours' box?
Anyone seen Dr. Weaver?
Follow the trail of partially-digested residents.
I've found a way to limit my Romano exposure.
Oh yeah, what's that? Garlic?
Students wanna be residents... residents wanna be attendings...
And attendings just wanna be left alone.

I've been doin' this job for 17 years, honey. Doctors come and go, but nurses make this place run. We don't get much credit or pay. We see a lot of misery, a lot of dyin', but we come back every day. I've given up bein' appreciated, but I sure as hell won't let any of us be taken for granted.
Luka's sleeping.
With who?
It's all ending today! Today is the last day!
Oh, great, I have to work. I'm always working when the world ends.
[Ross is a pediatrician]
I'm not a grown-up doctor.
Yes, we know.

[giving her large family the tour]
Back there is the suture room where we attend to minor skin wounds.
[a naked patient reveals himself]
That's a naked patient. Let's step this way.

[Greene and Lewis discussing the hospital gossip about them]
Mmm, yeah, and what is that, can I ask you? My car's in the shop, I drop Susie off at my parents, meet up with you to go tequila shopping, and all of a sudden we're having a torrid affair?
Who said it was torrid?
No one, I'm just assuming it would be.
[Greene looks at her]
That's not what I meant.
That's OK, I know what you meant... I'm sure it would be too... Why wouldn't it be?
...No reason at all.
[she stares at Greene and then at her margarita]
There's not enough lime in this.
This may sound silly now, but outside in the bay this morning, I was thinking about asking you out.
I was thinking about saying yes.

[after Abby caught him kissing Susan]
It's really more about friendship than anything else.
Really? I've never seen you kiss Frank like that.

[admiring Luka's dinner preparations]
Have you been watching Martha Stewart again?

All he did was talk about his ex for 45 minutes, who also happened to be named Susan. How much he loved her, how much he wanted to marry her, how much he wanted to have 5 or 6 children with her... Do I want children?... Do I want 5 or 6 children?
Okay, Tad could be worse.
I'm not even there yet, Mark. I look over, and he has this drop of red wine hanging from his nose.
What?
You heard me, this puny little blob just hanging there. So of course I couldn't take my eyes off of it. Is it gonna fall? is it gonna hang there all night? Is his skin gonna absorb it?
How did it get there?
Mark!
No really, how do you get your nose that far into a wine glass? Was he smelling it or...

[laughing]
Mark, please!
What happened?
I went to the bathroom and snuck out the window.
You're kidding.
Nope.
Wow.
Did you even take the Hippocratic Oath?
I had my fingers crossed.
Ladies, if I wanted to see a good cat fight I'd watch The View
We have a man with a large carrot stuck in his colon coming in.
How did he ever swallow it whole?
[In the OR]
Will somebody turn down the damn heat. Feels like a hundred in here.
The thermostat is set at 68 degrees.
Maybe you're coming down with the flu.
It's NOT the flu.
Maybe you're going through "The Change."
If men needed abortions, there would be drive-thru windows with beer on tap and ESPN on the TVs.
Dr. Clemente?
Just a minute, please.
Uh, well CT's calling about your patient Darrel Insley.
Yeah, so what did Big Darrel do now?
He stopped breathing.
And why the hell would he do that?
Try not to hit Morris with any desk tools.
I'm not promising anything.
Gus, how are you doing?
Haven't thrown up in an hour.
What about the other end?
It's slowing down.
That's what I like to hear.
I have the results from your blood exams. They show that you have leukemia.

[Takes a deep breath and resumes talking]
Thank God! I thought you were going to say I have cancer!
These are the desk clerks, Jerry and Frank, please don't feed them.
In what possible universe would I say "Let's polka?"
Last time he came in here, he yelled in my stethoscope.
He grabbed my ass. Suck it up.
...And if wishes were horses, we'd be knee-deep in crap.
How they holding up?
Stick a fork in them they've been Weavered.
I got stabbed! I got stabbed in the back! Where the hell where you? You were the same place you've been my entire life, you were someplace else!
That's it, Mark. I'm not stayin' here anymore. Every faucet leaks; your toilet actually rocks.
I kind of like that.
There are things scurrying about in the walls. Do you know what scurries about in walls, Mark?
Bunnies?
Dr. Ross, this came for you.
Bad news?
No. Just got denied a loan by a bank whose motto is "We loan money to anyone."

What were you thinking? What could you possibly have thought would happen tonight? That you would show up on my doorstep at midnight, drunk and I would find that as some sort grand gesture of love? That I would invite you back into my life, into my bed? Is that what you imagined would happen tonight? You have no right to even think about doing this.
I'm sorry.

Do you think you love me? For how long Doug? How long till you start wondering if there isn't someone better in the next room or the next bar? How long until that little voice in your head reminds you of all the infinite 22-year-olds you could be screwing tomorrow, or the next day, or the next? I will not let you do this to me again.
[exits]
I'm beginning to hate Neela.
Well, she's a med student.
I'm a med student!
To tell you the truth, she's starting to piss me off, too. Let's hate her together.

[to the bickering Chen and Malucci]
You know why we only had one kid? So I wouldn't have to deal with the two of them fighting in the backseat.

[describing Jodie]
She's kind of a looker, in an 'interstate off-ramp' kind of way.

[Instructing his med student]
Grab that penis and show it who's boss.
Larry took a bunch of pills, drank a bottle of gin, slit his wrists, and jumped into Lake Michigan.
Larry really wanted to die.
Oh man, I uh...
Don't worry dear, you're really very good at this.
Yeah, everybody loves your sessions.
Everybody except Larry.
I think you should talk to him, he seems depressed.
He's european, it's his baseline.

[about Gallant's twin sister]
What's she look like?
Picture me in a dress.

[examining a trauma patient]
Check it out, swastikas.
I've got a "die n- die" here.

[to the patient]
How do you feel about Asians?
Frank, are you taking your cholesterol medication?
No.
Good.
Okay, I'm gonna go to Doc Magoo's, get some breakfast, find a toothbrush, change my underwear, and then I'll clear your board.
You're nicer than I am.
That's not much solace.
I'm sorry.
I thought he froze to death last winter
The iceman cometh back.
Just a scalp lac. No LOC, and enough alcohol in her breath to light a small fire.
You might consider boarding school. She could use some structure
I could sell her off to pirates.
You develop a sense of self worth, community, respect... it worked well for me.
Yeah, but...
But what?
You're British.
You're the first woman I've talked to in 14 months.
Yeah, I get that a lot. In high school I was voted "Most Likely to marry a convict".
Hey, what do you use for maggots these days?
It's a nice thought, but Kerry's immune to it...
Our job is to save lives not to judge them.
You look tired.
Really?
Come to think of it, Frank looks tired, too.
Really?
Well, have you seen him getting down today?
Let's see. Frank! Have you gotten down today?
What?
Never mind.
[Randi is reading everyone's horoscope]
Hey, Abby. What's your sign?
"Out of order".
[Medical student Michael Gallant has worked in the army]
So working in the ER might not be so crazy to you.
Well, it's a different kind of "crazy".
A love story.
[about working in the ER]
It's really not so bad down here, Abby.
Oh yeah? Compared to what?
Hey, Chief, am I a yuppie?
No, but you will be when you grow up.
You get any freaks in here today? You know, guys with elephant man disease or axes stuck in their heads?
No!
Should you be looking at that?
I'm going to become a doctor.
Dollars to donuts, that kid is already dissecting the neighborhood pets.

[complaining about her tardy staff]
It's five after seven, is there some kind of natural disaster that I'm unaware of? An earthquake or half of Chicago's been swallowed up by a giant sinkhole?
Hey, those are nice shoes. What are they, Adidas?
Get laid, Morris.

You know what? I'm really very flattered. It's just that I'm, uh... I mean... gosh, you're such a beautiful woman. You're... you're so beautiful. But I'm... I... I'm straight... I mean, I don't... I'm straight. Oh, God. Oh, my God. I don't know... I don't know what's...
[starts laughing, then stops abruptly]
I mean, I'm sorry... I just... I don't... I feel very...
[exhales]
... I'm... You know what?... I... I just... I mean, I... I guess I never even really considered this.
You know, people think kids don't listen to their parents, but they do. And if you tell them they are nothing, they think they are nothing.
We've all cried... Sometimes it's the only thing you can do.
Did I miss anything?
Yes. Your calling, as a hoodlum.
you do not talk about girls' club.
Where'd you learn that trick?
What, sitting on a patient? I learned it from a congolese nurse named Mwadi.
What does R.W stand for?
Really whiney?
Refusal to walk.
Refusal to walk has its own abbreviation.
I feel like I'm in Junior High School again.

[Weaver approaches them]
Ooh, here comes the assistant principal.
For a long time, even when we weren't connecting a lot, you've... you've been the one person I can count on.
I feel like that, too. You know that means a lot to me, that friendship.

[Going over a new colour schedule]
Doug, you have a problem?
No, just call me Mr. Blue.
Doug can you help me out here. "If a red quark is attracted to an anti-red quark, is it a gluon or a meson?"
Thank you, Carol, for pointing out something else i know nothing about.
Oh, Doug, not another serious conversation.
You used to say we didn't communicate.
I know, but now you're communicating a little too much.
This is important. Can I have a drawer?
What?
A drawer. Something you keep your clothes in-something that i can put my clothes in.
You never wanted a drawer before.
Carter, take our friend here, I'm afraid I might stick an IV pole up his ass.
I'm having dinner with a guy.
Is he cute?
I think Weaver's got it in for me. I dont know what I ever did to Festus to get her so pissed.
Maybe it was calling her Festus.
Well, never to her face.

[Regarding Neela]
What is she, 10?
Actually, she's 16.

[while baby shopping]
Maybe a mobile of Croatian diplomats?
I'm a doctor and nothing gets in the way of that. Nothing.
The food was terrible, the music stinks, the drinks were watered down, but you sure know how to throw a party.

[looking at a snapshot of Jake]
Nah, boxers would stick out more.
It could be tighty whiteys.
Thong.
Hey, maybe Abby could settle this.
Abby, boxers or briefs?
Actually, he goes commando.
Why'd you stick me with this guy?
When did everyone become such scheduling divas?
Well, I don't need a student. I'm better flying solo.
Is there something wrong with him?
No, he's excellent. He's very good.
Oh, no, you like him, don't you?
Okay, you know what...?
You do! You're blushing!
We never had this conversation.
[starts to walk away]
Hey, haven't you had enough of doctors?
It's not a good idea to shock a patient who's wide-awake.
You're not the first to be deceived by my rugged good looks and boyish charm.
Why do I feel like a school kid out here?
It must be the adolescent sexual tension.
Hey Dr Greene.
[holds up a knife]
Surgery sent it down. Can I keep it?

[walks into chairs, and sees Lucy sitting in the middle of a luau group]
Hey, Luce, you just get here?
Bernard, what are you doing?

[looking around at the scene]
What happened?
Oh, some fire twirler burnt his butt, and the whole troupe's waiting for him.
I need you to promise me you're not going to kill yourself in the next seventy-two hours.
But Monday would be okay?
I'm off the hook by then.
Doctor Lewis!

[talking to herself]
And I used to think that was so cool to hear... "Doctor Lewis"...
So, what are you gonna do tonight?
Oh, the usual. Get drunk, meet a random guy at the bar and have a night of wild sex until I pass out from sheer exhaustion.
Takeout and a hot bath?
Yeah.

[to a patient strapped to a gurney]
What's your name, sir?
Edward Kaplin, call me Eddie. You the doc?
Yes I am. How are you feeling?
Haven't been tied up this tight since last Saturday night.
Thank you for sharing, Mr. Kaplin
So how was it... last night with the surgeon?
It was... splendid.
Splendid? Is the British for hot and sweaty?
Your talent is God's gift to you. What you do with it is your gift back to God.
No meat, no men, I'm your girl.

[playing on a Playstation]
Come on, we can hunt zombies together.
Couldn't we just, reason with them?
There are no small patients Carter...
What about dwarves?
You pulled all that out of patient's stomachs?
I sure did.
Is that my pen you pulled out?
Rear end.

I always knew you loved your children, but I never realized how much you fell in love with them. Little Susie was like a story book, every smile a new page to be poured over, touched, remembered... I loved my storybook. For the first time in a long time, I didn't feel so alone.
Tell your chief of staff I expect him to treat each of my patients as if it were his mother, but without all the inappropriate touching.
[Malucci is shooting hoops with a mini basketball net in the ER]
Need something to do, Malucci?
Uh, no thanks, Chief, I'm swamped.
[Dr. Weaver is about to throw a preacher out of the hospital]
Oh, no. Soon he'll start trying to heal people, and that's bad for business.

[Nicole made cookies]
They're for Luka. Want some?

[looking at Abby]
No, I would never touch Luka's cookies.
I can't wait to go home and get into bed. What do you think the chances are of Antonio Banderas waiting there for me?

[Telling Carol about when he did his physics exam]
He told us we could bring in one sheet into the exam with all the formulas written on it.
And?
I brought in a really big sheet.
What do you do to work out?
I do these
[curls arm]
Curls? How much?
Sometimes a whole pitcher of magaritas.

[to Dr. Romano]
You're a despicable human being. Do you know that?"
You know, earlier, in the ambulance bay, I was thinking of asking you out.
And I was thinking of saying yes.

[after Ray begs her to allow his roommate to stay]
Fine, but you're cleaning the bathroom this week... with actual cleaning products.

[after Carter arrives]
Glad you're here. Your fan club is getting restless.
What is it with you and nuns, Carter?
It's almost kinky.
If we were guys, we'd be talking about carbureters.
Is anybody in this city not sick? It's like the damn plague down here.
Good news and bad news. The bad news is my enlarged prostate guy needs a tube shoved up his urethra. The good news is he gets to have you in his pants.
Don't touch it! It hurts!
We're gonna take care of that.
Oh, God, I see a light!
You're not dying. It's just your ankle.
Oh, God! Ohhhhh!

[showing medical students around]
Most interns send their samples without knowing what happens once they're there. Let's pretend we're a urine sample and find out.
If I was stuck on a train with my family... Well bad example, I'd throw myself on the tracks.
[On a rapist in trauma]
Let the bastard die.
He's a patient like any other. He gets our best effort.
It's a bizarre thing, Daniel, which makes you a very bizarre guy, but we like that around here.
Yep, almost midnight. Let the screaming begin.
So you say you're sick, you're broke, you're unemployed and uninsured. Yea, sure, come on over.
Can you help me with this?
[hands Susan a bunch of X-Ray results]
Well, I've denied my bladder this long...
I'm going to become a doctor when I grow up.
Dollars to donuts that kid's already dissecting neighborhood pets.
food, sports and sex. Dogs are more mysterious.
Self respect's a bitch.

[to Luka, while playing a video game]
Bite me, you Slav bastard.
Are you okay?
Yeah. I'm blind, getting blinder every day. Life is good.
Happy Hannukah, Kwanza, whatever...

[to young patient]
Next time you have a pinata, make sure the other kids are done swinging at it before you dive for the candy, okay?
You ever flown before?
Yeah, tons of times.
You can run but you cannot hide!
Chocolate?
Too early. We like bagels in the morning.

[about Jake]
No need to talk about it?
No, denial works.
